function_call.name: classify_risks_framework
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Uncertainty in the state and measurement models","category":"Structure","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Reliance on unknown parameters in people movement models for building occupancy estimation","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inability to obtain real people flow data during emergency egress situations","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Computational expense and potential stability issues in optimization-based people flow estimation methods","category":"Structures","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Study funding without involvement in the study may raise questions about the independence and bias of the research findings.","category":"Society","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Incomplete disclosure of the funding sources and the lack of involvement may lead to perceptions of conflict of interests or hidden agendas.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Potential influence of the funding bodies on the dissemination and interpretation of the research findings, despite lack of involvement in the study.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Incomplete investigation of shelter-in-place variables for covid-19 spread.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Unintuitive associations between the built environment be attributes and infection cases.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Need for more spatially fine data to measure the influence of the built environment be attributes on disease spread.","category":"Structure","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Association of built environment attributes with the spread of covid-19 in china","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Differences in the associations of built environment attributes in different geographical locations","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Restricting inter-city connections via railways may prevent the further spread of covid-19 in most cities of all levels.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lowering the betweenness centrality could slow down the spread of future pandemics in over 70% of prefectural-level cities.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Reducing the population densities of built-up areas could be effective in preventing the spread of future pandemics in approximately 70.00 % of the province capitals.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Association between the number of trains and the spread of covid-19","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Impact of population flow on covid-19 spread","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Effect of aging population percentage on covid-19 spread","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Positive coefficients of population flow correlated with higher infection ratios","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Positive correlation between population density and infection ratio","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Differences in infection ratio relationships between inland and coastal areas","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Positive association of between-ness centrality with the spread of covid-19 in cities under study, widely distributed in china.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Negative impacts of between-ness centrality on the spread of covid-19 in southwestern china and the yangtze river delta.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Positive association between the percentage of aging population and the spread of covid-19 in certain cities in china.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Positive coefficients for most cities across the country and statistically significant at the 0.01 level, except for the northwestern cities.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Negative coefficients observed in only a handful of sub-provincial cities and prefecture-level cities, but not statistically significant.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Higher coefficients in county-level cities with 36.36% showing the highest coefficient range.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"The spread of covid-19 is associated with the number of trains, population flow, and percentage of the aging population.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"The coefficients with local effects have both negative and positive estimates, indicating a mixed association with covid-19 spread.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"The spatial distributions of the associations of built environment attributes with the spread of covid-19 are illustrated.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Density of pois around railway stations positively associated with infection ratio","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Low airline coverage from hubei province to county-level cities in china","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Travel time by public transport negatively related to infection ratio","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Dependent variable is infection ratio","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Standardized explanatory variables","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Use of gwr and mlr models for comparison","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Spatial clustering of variables may indicate localized hotspots of disease transmission or contagion spread.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Spatial clusters of covid-19 spread indicating high infection ratios in specific regions.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"The large-scale population movement from hubei province via trains increases the risk of disease spread.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Density of points of interest pois around railway stations increases face-to-face contact and potential disease transmission.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Population flow from hubei province and number of flights from hubei increase the risk of disease spread between cities.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of consideration for spatial autocorrelation in disease spread analysis","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Misinterpretation of global and local effects in the mixed gwr model","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Assumption of spatial stationarity in explanatory variables in the mlr model","category":"Structure","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Vulnerability of elderly people to covid-19","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Spatial clusters of infection cases","category":"Structure","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Concentration of activities around railway stations leading to quick transfer of infected persons to urban areas","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Population density of built-up areas affecting spread and decay patterns of covid-19","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Vulnerability of elderly people to contagious diseases like covid-19","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Use of spatial connection and analysis tools may result in inaccurate identification of activity centers.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"}]}
